metadata.case_name: Talkeshwari Devi v. Husband of Sheorani Kuer

facts.text: Raghunath Prasad Singh executed a will on August 31, 1938, and died very soon after.
Testator left behind widow Jageshwar Kuer, daughter Satrupa Kuer alias Nan, and two granddaughters Talkeshwari Devi (appellant) and Sheorani Kuer, daughters of predeceased son Sukhdeo Prasad Singh.
Sheorani Devi died on November 1, 1949 without leaving any issue.
Will provides: After testator's death, portion of properties to Jageshwar Kuer absolutely; remaining properties to her with life interest.

After Jageshwar Kuer's death, entire property as 16 annas: 5 annas 4 pies to Satrupa Kuer and heirs absolutely; remaining 10 annas 8 pies to minor granddaughters Talkeshwari and Sheorani in equal shares as absolute proprietary interest (clause 4).
Clause 5: If one of the two granddaughters dies issueless, the other living granddaughter will enter into possession of the entire 10 annas 8 pies and become absolute owner.
At testator's death, appellant and Sheorani were minors.
After Jageshwar Kuer's death, appellant and Sheorani divided the 10 annas 8 pies share equally and each took possession.
Immediately after Sheorani's death, appellant instituted suit for possession of Sheorani's share based on clause 5.
Suit resisted by first defendant (Sheorani's husband), claiming as her heir.
Trial court dismissed plaintiff's suit; Patna High Court upheld in First Appeal No. 113 of 1960 on February 17, 1965.
Genuineness or validity of will not in dispute.

legal_issues.text: Effect of the will executed by Raghunath Prasad Singh, particularly whether clause 5 entitles appellant to Sheorani's share after her death issueless, or if properties devolved absolutely under clause 4.

petitioner_arguments.text: In view of clause 5 of the will, appellant is entitled to suit properties as Sheorani died issueless.
Governing provision is Section 131 of Indian Succession Act, 1925, contemplating divestment of vested estate.

respondent_arguments.text: Entitled to properties as heir of wife Sheorani.

court_reasoning.text: Duty of court to find intention of testator from language of will read as a whole; clause 4 gives granddaughters absolute right after Jageshwar's death, not conditional estate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Estate bequeathed under clause 4 is not a conditional estate.

court_reasoning.text: Clause 5 relates to devolution, not divestment of vested estate; refers to devolution when properties devolved on two sisters on death of Jageshwar Kuer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Clause 5 cannot be considered as a defeasance clause.

court_reasoning.text: No conflict between clauses 4 and 5; clause 5 would operate if contingency happened before properties devolved absolutely on sisters.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Testator intended if granddaughter dies issueless before devolution, entire property to other.

court_reasoning.text: Section 124, Indian Succession Act, 1925 applies: legacy cannot take effect unless uncertain event happens before fund payable/distributable; contingency did not occur before distribution after Jageshwar's death.
Section 131 deals with divestment of vested estate, but clause 5 is not defeasance clause.
Similar to Norendra Nath Sircar v. Kamal Basini Dasi, where contingent legacy did not take effect as event did not happen before distribution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Relied on s.111 of 1865 Act (similar to s.124 of 1925 Act).

holdings.text: Clause 5 ceased to be operative on death of Jageshwar Kuer; thereafter clause 4 operative, giving absolute estate to granddaughters; no divestment.
Section 124 applies, not s.131; legacy to appellant unavailable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Norendra Nath Sircar and anr. v. Kamal Basini Dasi
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar will clause interpreted as contingent legacy not taking effect if event after distribution; relied on s.111 Indian Succession Act, 1865 (similar to s.124, 1925 Act).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Succession Act, 1925
statutes_cited.relevance: S.124 governs contingent legacies/devolution; s.131 governs divestment of vested estates. S.124 applies here.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Succession Act, 1865
statutes_cited.relevance: Similar to s.124 of 1925 Act; applied in cited precedent.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court agrees with courts below that suit is unsustainable; appeal by certificate dismissed.

key_quotes.text: It is clear from clause 4 of the will that the testator wanted to give to his grand-daughters an absolute right in the properties that were to devolve on them after the death of his wife, Jageshwar Kuer.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Clause 5 of the will relates to devolution and it does not provide for any divestment of an estate which had vested.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: If s. 124 applies to the facts of the case, as we think it does, then it is clear that the legacy claimed by the appellant is unavailable.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Applies Succession Act to bar appellant's claim.
